texts.en: Sreyny, 42, sells sugar cane juice and cake with her husband and their income is $7 per day. She has four children, aged 13, 9, 4 and 2. Each month, she has to spend $30 on food, $5 on electricity, $10 on school fees and $15 on transportation. She would like to request a loan of $700 to buy a motorbike for transporting her sugar cane juice machine to sell in other places. She doesn't yet want to think of changing her career because it can make good income to support her family. She wants to send her children to university after they finish high school.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for taking her sugar cane juice machine to sell in different places.

loans.name: Genevive

texts.en:
Genevive, 33, is married with two children, aged 11 and three. She and her husband are both farmers. Now that they have a sari sari store and eatery, her husband mainly manages their rice farm while Genevive runs the store and eatery. She cooks the food that they sell and also helps in selling their harvest at the market.

Genevive has requested a loan to fund their farm. She plans to purchase four sacks of rice seeds, three sacks of fertilizers and to pay for tractor rental. Genevive hopes for their ventures to succeed and for her children to finish their studies.

loans.use: to purchase four sacks of rice seeds, three sacks of fertilizers and to pay for renting a tractor.

loans.name: Kurbonali

texts.en:
Kurbonali is a hardworking and active farmer. He is married and the father of two children. He is engaged in animal husbandry and he has been running his business for eight years. Kurbonali keeps his cattle near his house and at any time he can visit his cattle. 

Kurbonali would like to increase the number of his cattle and make a good profit. With the loan he plans to buy cattle and feed for his cattle. With this aim he has requested a loan of 800 USD. He hopes that the lenders will help him and allow him to expand his business.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy cattle and feed.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
This is Elizabeth, 53, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Bernardino, an employee, and a mother to her three children who are all working. Together with her husband, she manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Elizabeth maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller Life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalog, and these are the profits that dealers count on as their income. Elizabeth's regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php1250 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 22,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Elizabeth dreams of expanding her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for merchandise items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Edeliza

texts.en:
This is Edeliza, 48, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Eduardo, a driver, and mother of four children. Together with her husband, she manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Edeliza operates a rug-making business. She mainly offers rugs, from round palm-sized ones to the much larger doormats, braided quilts and bed sheets, and other crafts that most rug-makers offer every day. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding "jeepney" (minibus) down the highway. She also earns additional income from their "tricycle" which her husband drives regularly. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 750 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 22,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials for her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Edeliza dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials she uses in her business.

loans.name: Rohat

texts.en:
Rohat is a hard-working woman. She is married and the mother of three children. Rohat has been in the bakery business for 15 years with her sister. She cooks tasty breads and then sells them in the local market of “Farovon”. She would like to get a loan of 1900 USD for purchasing flour and coal in order to expand her business and increase her working capital. We believe this current loan will enhance the potential of her business and help Rohat reach all of her aspirations.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy flour and coal reserves.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
This is Gina, 42, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Ador, a laborer, and  mother to her three children. Together with her husband and children, she manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses. 

Gina operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Gina earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located near the roadside in their community. She also cooks snack food that she sells in the afternoon. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 550 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 19,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Gina hopes to expand soon and acquire a good place for her store. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and  also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Nazarenos Group

texts.es:
La señora Lilia es integrante de una unidad de desarrollo (UDE) la cual esta conformado por diez personas los culaes han decidido llamarla Nazareno en honor al nombre de su comunidad.
La señora Lilia tiene la edad de 37 años, solo estudio la secundaria, y esta casada con el señor Raul el cual se dedica al trabajo del campo, hace mas de 6 años una amiga la invito a trabajar con ella vendiendo antojitos Mexicanos, dulces y agua a la hora del recreo en la escuela primaria de su localidad y ella acepto ya que deseaba ganar un poco de dinero extra ya que cada dia la situacion economica esta peor, asi con lo que ganaba poder dar una mejor calidad de vida a su familia, ella nos dice que gracias a esta oportunidad de trabajo ha logrado tener su propio negocio y trabaja fuerte para hacerlo crecer dia a dia. 
Ella necesita este credito para invertirlo en la compra de chiles, tomates, cebolla, carne, col, cilantro, maiz, crema y queso para elaboracion de su comida y posteriormente venderla, además de diversos dulces tambien para ofrecerlos.
Ella realiza sus ventas de lunes a viernes a las 11:00 de la mañana. Tambien nos comenta que desea que su negocio prospere dia a dia mas para poder en un futuro pagar la univerdad de sus hijos y darle la oportunidad de tener mejor calidad de vida.
Los demas integrantes son:

Pablo - Abarrotes
Epifanio - Taller Mecanico
Martha Graciela- Refrescos
Cristina - Refrescos
Lourdes - Refrescos
Genoveva - Molino
Ma. de los Angeles - Refresco
Julia - Abarrotos
Linda - Antojitos
texts.en:
Lilia is a member of a communal bank or development unit (UDE) which is made up of ten people, who decided to call it Nazareno in honor of the name of their community. 

Lilia is 37 years old. She studied only through secondary school. She is married to Raul, who is an agricultural worker. More than 6 years ago, a friend invited Lilia to work with her selling Mexican foods, sweets and water during recess at the primary school of their town. She accepted, since she wanted to earn a little bit of extra money, because every day the economic situation is getting worse. Thus, with her earnings, she can give a better quality of life to her family. She reports that thanks to this work opportunity, she has been able to have her own business, and she works hard to make it grow day by day. 
 
She needs this loan to invest it in buying chiles, tomatoes, onions, meat, cabbage, cilantro, corn, cream and cheese to prepare her foods to sell, in addition to various sweets which she will also sell. 

She sells her products from Monday through Friday at 11:00 a.m. She also comments that she wants her business to prosper more each day so that in the future she can pay for university studies for her children and give them the opportunity to have a better quality of life. 

The other members of the group are:

Pablo - Groceries
Epifanio - Mechanic's workshop
Martha Graciela- Soft drinks
Cristina - Soft drinks
Lourdes - Soft drinks
Genoveva - Grain mill 
Ma. de los Angeles - Soft drinks
Julia - Groceries
Linda - Mexican foods.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for the food she sells.

loans.name: Jade Group

texts.es: Este grupo solidario se llama Jade esta conformado por las señoras Maria Guadalupe y Lourdes van a comprar con su prestamo harina,azucar, pintura, bolsas, aceite, lija, cinta canela para elaboracion de obleas, el señor Virgilio va a comprar harina, azucar, manteca y leña para la ellaboracion de pan, las señoras Carina y Ofelia van a comprar obleas por paquete para recortarlas, empaquetarlas y venderlas. La señora Maria Guadalupe tiene 38 años de edad, ella es casada tiene 4 hijos tres mujeres y un hombre, todos sus hijos estan estudiando, su hija mayor en bachilleres, dos en la secundaria y su niña mas pequeña en la primaria, ella elabora y vende obleas, ella solicito su credito para comprar harina, pintura, aceite, azucar, bolsas para tener todo lo necesario para su negocio, ella inicio su negocio hace 6 años, sus hijos estaban pequeños y habia carencias economicas, entonces su prima le enseño a preparar la mezcla para elaborar las obleas, su esposo le compra las maquinas de obleas y la materia prima con un dinero que tenia ahorrado, asi comenzo el negocio de obleas, a ella le gusta trabajar y ayudarle a sus esposo y tener dinero para vivir mejor, su negocio es importante porque tiene su porpio trabajo, tiene ingresos y le puede dar trabajo a otras personas en la elaboracion de obleas, ella se siente orgullosa de su negocio le ayuda a comprar algunos articulos para el hogar como su lavadora, la grabadora, sus sueños y esperanzas son que Dios le de vida y pueda construir una bodega especial para trabajar, comprar un carro para ir a vender las obleas, hacer creser su negocio, que sus hijos sigan estudiando y tengan su carrera y tengan un buen trabajo de gobierno. Las integrantes del grupo quieren decirle a Kiva y a Fundacion Realidad "muchas gracias por pensar en las personas que tienen negocio y tenemos la necesidad de estos prestamos para seguir trabajando en nuestros negocios".
texts.en:
This group is called “Jade” and is composed of María Guadalupe and Lourdes.  They are going to use their loan to buy flour, sugar, food coloring, bags, oil, ribbons, tape and cinnamon to make wafers.  Virgilio is going to buy flour, sugar, shortening and firewood to bake bread.  Carina and Ofelia are going to buy wafers by the package to repackage in smaller amounts and sell.  

María Guadalupe is 38 years old, married and has four children: three girls and one boy.  All her children are in school.  Her oldest daughter is in high school, the next two are in middle school and her youngest daughter is in elementary school.

She makes ‘obleas’ (sweet made from two thin wafers stuffed with caramel) and requested the loan to buy flour, food coloring, oil, sugar and bags to have everything necessary for her business.  She started the business six years ago.  Her children were small and she had economic needs so her cousin taught her how to prepare the dough for the wafers.  Her husband bought her the machines to make them and she used savings she had to buy the raw materials.  This is how the obleas business started.  

She likes to work to help her husband and to have money to live better.  Her business is important because she has her own job, earn income and can employ others manufacturing obleas.  She is proud of her business.  It helps her buy some items for the home like her washing machine and the tape recorder.  Her dreams and hopes are that God grants her life so that she can manage to build a warehouse to work in, to buy a car to sell the obleas, to help her business to grow and that her children stay in school and attain careers and good jobs with the government.

The group members would like to say to Kiva and Fundación Realidad:  “many thanks for thinking about people who have businesses and need these loans to continue working in our businesses.”

loans.use: To buy flour, food coloring, oil, sugar and bags to make wafers.

loans.name: Maxima

texts.en:
This is Maxima, 49, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Nicanor, a security guard, and mother to their children. Together with her husband and children, she manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses and support her children’s schooling. 

Maxima operate a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Maxima earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Maxima hopes to expand soon, just as she fervently hopes that her children will be able to graduate one day, and finish their studies. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business

loans.name: El Polvorin Group

texts.es:
La señora Reyna tiene 30 años de edad la localidad donde vive es muy prolifero el cultivo de aguacate, ella es casada y su esposo es jornalero y tienen una hija la cual estudia la primaria. Doña Reyna pertenece a un grupo de crédito llamado “El Polvorín”  comenta que le pusieron es nombre por que así le dicen a la colonia donde vive. Ella es una mujer trabajadora y muy activa ella tiene una tienda de abarrotes desde hace 6 años dice que emprendió ese negocio para estar mas al pendiente de sus hijos. Ella esta pidiendo un crédito a la financiera para comprar productos para tener surtida su tienda de abarrotes como azúcar, jabón, leche, café, huevo, arroz y artículos de primera necesidad etc. ella se va a surtir a una población cercana a la de ella en supermercados donde le dan bajos precios para que después ella pueda ganarles algo. La meta que tiene la señora Reyna es mas adelante poner un local de cemento ya que donde tiene sus productos es un cuartito de madera ella quisiera ponerse ahorrar para hacer su local y tener muy bien surtido su negocio ya que es la fuente de empleo muy importante para ella.
Los otros nueve integrantes se llaman Catalina, María Guadalupe, Diana Martina, Rosa María, María Isabel, Adela, Ana Luisa, Ygnacia y Gabriel ellos invertirán su crédito que les están otorgando en diferentes negocios como en puesto de frutas y legumbres, en ropa para dama por catalogo, puesto de dulces, en una florería.
texts.en:
Reyna is 30 years old.  In the locality where she lives avocadoes grow profusely.  She’s married and her husband’s a day laborer.  They have a daughter who is in elementary school.  

Reyna belongs to a credit group called “El Polvorín” (Powder Keg).  She comments that they chose that name because that’s what their neighborhood is called.  She is a very hardworking, very active woman.  She’s had a grocery store for the last six years.  She says she started this business in order to be able to be more watchful of her children.  

She is asking the financial agency for a loan to buy stock merchandise for her store like: sugar, soap, milk, coffee, eggs, rice and basic need items.  She goes to a nearby town to stock up on goods at a supermarket there where prices are lower and she can then earn a bit of profit.  

Reyna’s goal is to build a space later on out of cement because she currently keeps her products in a little wooden room.  She’d like to start to save up and have her business very well stocked because this is a very important source of employment for her.

The other nine group members are: Catalina, María Guadalupe, Diana Martina, Rosa María, María Isabel, Adela, Ana Luisa, Ygnacia and Gabriel.  They will use the loan they are getting in various businesses like: fruit and vegetable stand, women’s catalogue clothing sales, candy stand and a flower shop.

loans.use: to buy stock items for her grocery store.

loans.name: Libertad Group

texts.es: Este grupo solidario se llama Libertad se localiza en un lugar que se caracteriza por ser montañoso con mucha vegetacion y arboles frutales como el aguacate, durazno etc.  está conformado por la señora Ana Bertha va a comprar con su crédito carnes frías, verduras, bolsas, la señora Alma Rosa va a comprar catálogos para vender lencería y cosméticos, la señora Mayra Nayeli va a comprar catálogos de temporada y zapatos, la señora Aleida va a comprar dulces,  la señora Leonor va a comprar un extractor, una sombrilla, naranjas, zanahorias, betabel para elaborar jugos. La señora Mayra Nayeli tiene 31 años de edad, ella vive en unión libre con su esposo tienen 4 hijos tres mujeres y un hombre los dos más grandes estudian, ella vende zapatos por catalogo ella solicito su crédito para comprar los catálogos nuevos y zapatos de dama, caballero y niño para surtir sus pedidos, ella inicio su negocio hace 4 años ella aprendió sola, su negocio es ambulante sale a ofrecer sus productos con sus vecinas, amistades y familiares, este negocio es importante porque le ayuda en el ingreso económico a adquirir zapatos para sus hijos, ella recuerda que en una ocasión tuvo buenas ganancias y con eso pago las colegiaturas de sus hijos por eso está muy contenta con su trabajo, ella está planeando vender ropa por cataloga y ofrecer sus productos por tandas para que no se les haga pesado a sus clientes, ella se siente orgullosa de poder darles a sus clientes facilidades en los pagos de los zapatos y se siente feliz con este préstamo que va a recibir porque va a tener dinero para surtir sus pedidos y crecer su negocio. Las ganancias las distribuye en los gastos de la familia, para la escuela de sus hijos y otra parte para  volver a invertir, sus sueños y esperanzas son tener un local bien establecido donde tenga zapatos para ofrecer a sus clientes y atender amablemente a los clientes mostrarles los catálogos y que sus hijos tengan una buena educación. Las integrantes del grupo quieren decirle a Kiva y a Fundación Realidad “gracias por sus préstamos y que continúen con esta labor porque benefician a las familias a tener su propio negocio”.
texts.en:
This group is called “Libertad” (Liberty) and is located in a place that’s mountainous and has lots of vegetation and fruit trees like avocadoes, peaches, etc.  

It’s members are Ana Bertha who will use her loan to buy cold cuts, vegetables and bags; Alma Rosa, who will buy catalogues to sell lingerie and cosmetics; Mayra Nayeli, who will buy seasonal catalogues and shoe catalogues; Aleida, who will buy candy; Leonor, who will by a juicer, an umbrella, oranges, carrots and beets to make juice.

Mayra Nayeli is 31 years old.  She’s in a common law relationship and she and her husband have four children; three girls and one boy.  The two oldest are in school.  She sells shoes via catalogue.  She requested her loan to buy new catalogues and women’s, men’s and children’s shoes to fill her pending orders.  She started the business four years ago learning it on her own.  She’s a street vendor.  She goes out to offer her wares to neighbors, friends and family members.  

This business is important because it helps her earn income and acquire shoes for her children.  She recalls that on one occasion she had good profits and was able to pay her children’s school tuition; this is why she’s happy with her work.  She’s planning to sell clothes via catalogue and to sell on credit so that it won’t be so taxing on her customers.  She feels proud to be able to offer easy payment plans to her customers to pay for their shoes and she’s happy with this loan that she’s going to get because she’ll have money to fill her orders and help her business to grow.

She uses profits to pay family expenses, to pay for her children’s schooling and part of it to reinvest.  Her dreams and hopes are to have a well-established locale where she can have shoes to offer her customers and to take care of them kindly, to show them the catalogues and that her children have good educations.

The group members would like to say to Kiva and to Fundación Realidad: “Thank for your loans and please continue with this labor because you benefit families to have their own business.”

loans.use: to buy catalogues and women's, men's and children's shoes to fill her orders.

loans.name: Avelina

texts.en:
This is Avelina, 61, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is a widow with three children who are already working and have families. Together with her youngest child she manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.

Avelina operates a video/karaoke and Ready-To-Wear (RTW) merchandise shop. She provides a place in her house to be used by customers who want to rent the video/karaoke machine. She also earns by selling RTW merchandise and cookies. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 1050 in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 14,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to for the maintenance of her video/karaoke machine and to add RTW merchandise needed in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Avelina dreams of being able to renovate her house to expand her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for merchandise and for the maintenance of her video/karaoke machine.

loans.name: Santa Rosa  La Nueva Esperanza Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama  Santa  Rosa  La   Nueva   Esperanza , sus integrantes decidieron ponerle así  por así se llama  su  pueblo , y encontraron en fundación  realidad  la esperanza  para cambiar su vida.
El grupo esta conformado por once integrantes,  y tienen que reunirse cada semana para realizar sus  pagos.
La representante de este grupo es la señora  Flor  Guadalupe  tiene  treinta y ocho años de edad, tiene 2 hijas Clara Luisa de catorce años de edad estudia la secundaria y Fátima de  diez años quien estudia la primaria .
La  señora  Flor Guadalupe   se dedica a la  venta de antojitos mexicanos  y  pollos, necesita el préstamo para comprar mas pollos ya que rápido se le termina, sus  clientes le compran por mayoreo por, esa razón  termina rápido.
Sus clientes le recomiendan que compre mas pollos por que en ocasiones  rápido se le termina.
Uno de sus sueños es tener una pillería mas grande ya  que a sus clientes les gusta como les despacha, están  muy contentos con el servicio que les brinda.
Los  integrantes se llaman:
Francisca - necesita el préstamo  para la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Fidelina- necesita el préstamo para la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Angélica-  necesita el préstamo para la venta de refresco.
Yesenia-necesita el préstamo para la venta de carnes frías.
Alejandra-necesita el préstamo para la  venta de comida.
María  Luisa – necesita el préstamo para la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Soledad-necesita el préstamo para la venta de quesos.
Isabel –necesita el préstamo  para la  venta de pollos.
Alba- necesita el préstamo para la venta de pollos.
Adriana- necesita el préstamo par la venta de antojitos mexicanos.

Le dan las gracias a fundación realidad  por dale la esperanza  para empezar sus propios negocios y tener  una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
This group is called Santa Rosa La Nueva Esperanza (Santa Rosa the New Hope).  Its members decided to call it this because that is the name of their town, and in Fundación Realidad they found the hope of changing their lives. There are 11 members in the group, and they meet each week to make their payments. 

The representative of this group is Flor Guadalupe.  She is 38 years old, and has two daughters: Clara Luisa, 14, goes to high school, and Fatima, 10, goes to primary school.  Flor Guadalupe sells chickens and Mexican dishes. She needs the loan to buy more chickens, since she runs out quickly. Her customers buy from her wholesale, and that's why she runs out quickly. Her customers recommend that she buy more chickens because sometimes she runs out quickly. One of her dreams is to have a larger store, since her customers like how she serves them. They are very happy with the service she offers.  The members are:

Francisca - She needs the loan to sell Mexican dishes
Fidelina - She needs the loan to sell Mexican dishes
Angélica - She needs the loan to sell soft drinks
Yesenia - She needs the loan to sell cold cuts
Alejandra - She needs the loan to sell food
María Luisa She needs the loan to buy Mexican dishes
Soledad - She needs the loan to sell cheeses
Isabel - She needs the loan to sell chickens
Alba - She needs the loan to sell chickens
Adriana- She needs the loan to sell Mexican dishes

They are thankful to Fundación Realidad for giving them the hope of starting their own businesses, and of having a better quality of life.

loans.use: To buy and sell chickens at wholesale and retail

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use:
Compra de carne, verduras, pan, aceite, maiz, tortillas
To buy meat, vegetables, bread, cooking oil, corn, tortillas

loans.name: Inobat

texts.en:
Inobat is a hard-working and responsible woman. She is married and the mother of one child. She is engaged in the farming business and she cultivates vegetables. Every day she gets up early and goes to her farm. Her crops are growing well and she wants to expand her business and increase her crops. 

Inobat would like to get a loan of 1000 USD for purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizers. She plans to use part of the loan for payment of her workers. She hopes that the lenders will support her. Thank you! 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy seeds, mineral fertilizers and pay workers.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
This is Lolita, 36, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Larson, a security personnel, and mother to her six children. The oldest is in high school while three are in elementary and two are not yet studying. Together with her husband and children, she manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Lolita is a mineral water distributor. What she basically does is buy mineral water in containers from wholesalers and sell it per container (5 gallons per container) at a profit. She also earns additional income by selling fruit in her husband’s work place. Her regular customers for her mineral water are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php700 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more mineral water and seasonal fruit to expand her product. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Lolita dreams of being able to give all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have a growing network of customers. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for stocks of mineral water and fruit needed in her business.

loans.name: Munkhbold

texts.en:
Mr. Munkhbold, 28 and a marketing manager in a private company, lives with his wife and son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He has been working as a manager since last year but his salary is not enough for his family. So he wants to run a taxi business after his work on weekdays or weekends. It is beneficial for his family income and to improve their quality of life. 

Starting a taxi service calls for a good and solid car. And he needs a financial support with the car payments. Therefore Munkhbold is taking a loan to aggregate his car payments so he can afford to start a taxi business.

loans.use: To aggregate his car payments so he can afford to start a taxi business.

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
This is Nida, 43, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Edgardo, a street vendor, and a mother to her four children. The oldest is in college while the youngest is staying at home. Together with her husband and children, she manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses. 

Nida operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Nida earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Nida hopes to expand soon. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana is 30 years old. She is married and has two children. Juliana began earning income selling seasonal vegetables and fruits. She has eight years of experience in this field. After a while, she began working at other jobs, but realized that her work wasn't bringing in enough income to cover the expenses of her family. 

Therefore, Juliana decided to independently reengage in the seasonal vegetable sales business. Gradually, she is becoming known in the area; however, she still needs additional capital to purchase vegetables and fruit for sale, given the high demand during the current season. Julina is asking for a loan of P 7,000. With this money, Juliana will be able to buy additional fruit and vegetables for sale and thus earn more profit.

Juliana has a good client history and she is thankful to everyone for their support.

loans.use: to buy cabbage, pineapple, beans and watermelon for her roving store.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph, 27, is married. His spouse works as an assistant in their community. Joseph has raised pigs for two years.

Joseph  is asking for a loan of P 5,000 that he intends to use to buy feed concentrate to fatten up his pigs. He has several pigs in his possession and he intends to feed them concentrate to fatten them up more quickly. He wants his animals to reach ideal weight to sell them locally and in nearby markets. He wants to earn higher profits for his family.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for his piglets.

loans.name: Jomar

texts.en:
Jomar, 44, is married and lives with his three children and his wife, who are his main priority. With this loan he plans to buy supplies for his rice crops. He has some empty land that has nothing planted on it, and so he will plant rice there to use the land and derive benefit from it. He wants to plant his crops under good conditions so that he can take maximum advantage of the land. 

Jomar is requesting a loan of P 15,000 to buy rice seeds, fertilizer and pay some other farm expenses.

His goal is to obtain the earnings he needs to get ahead and provide for the well-being of his family. He also wants to save to provide for his security in the future.

loans.use: to buy rice seeds, fertilizer, and pay some other farm expenses.

loans.name: Gracelda

texts.en:
Gracelda is 35 years old and lives in Canubay, Oroquieta City. She is widowed with four children. 

To earn a living, she  has a business selling fish. She earns about PHP 2,000 each month doing this type of work. Gracelda has  requested a loan in the amount of 10,000 to purchase more fish to sell.

Gracelda has been a member of PMPC for two years.  In the future, Gracelda would like to have a lot of capital for her fish vending.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn, a married woman living in the land of her birth, has four children residing with her and her husband. Both farmers, she and her husband work hard to support their family by raising livestock and growing crops. They arise at dawn everyday to cut grass to feed the cows and check the fields to ensure optimal crop growth and guard against insect infestations. Occasionally, Jocelyn sells the offspring of her cows, especially if they are males. Now requesting a loan of P 15,000 to buy sacks of rice, fertilizer and corn seeds, she plans to improve their crop production.

loans.use: to buy seed and fertilizer.

loans.name: Johny

texts.en:
Johny is 44 years old, married with three grown-up children. He keeps livestock and cultivates land. Johny would like to start growing rice, as it is in great demand. Rice farming requires much work, so Johny plans to hire workers to help.

With the requested loan of P 15,000 he plans to purchase rice seeds, fertilizer and pay the salaries of the workers for his farm business. Johny will increase his income and improve his family’s living conditions.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, seeds to plant, and pay for plowing costs on his farm.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna is 56 years of age. She is married to Teofilo who is a utility worker in a private hospital in Tuguegarao City. 

Edna is involved in providing sewing services to the people in her village. Instead of staying in the house and just doing household chores, she sews school and office uniforms, tablecloths, pillow cases and curtains. She has been in the business for more than 10 years. 

Early in the morning, she also buys and sells "yakult" (a pro-biotic milk drink made by fermenting skim milk powder, water and sugar with a strain of good bacteria) in her neighborhood. She usually earns about P10,000 each month doing these activities. Income generated from the business goes to the children's education and the family's daily consumption. 

Edna is now requesting a loan of P15,000 to buy fabrics, thread and needles used in sewing. She hopes to grow her business with the help of this loan. Edna believes that being flexible and creative in her business will help her improve her services and generate more income and soon will make her financially stable.

loans.use: to buy fabrics, thread and needles used in sewing.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma is 42 years old and married to Remerico who is a local farmer . They live in Dalaoig, Alcala, Cagayan. The couple was blessed with four children and all are attending school. Gemma and Remerico plant and harvest rice for future sale. 

As farmers working in the Philippines, they usually earn about P 50,000 each crop season (May and November). Profits earned go to school fees and sundry needs at home like daily meals and electric bills. 

Gemma is now requesting a loan of P 15,000 to buy seeds, fertilizers and moluscicides (chemicals used to kill snails) used in farming. She hopes that her crop will produce more yield to increase her profits.

In the future, Gemma hopes to earn consistent profits to continuously send her children to school and earn a degree to have a brighter future someday.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers and moluscicides used in farming.

loans.name: Patricio

texts.en:
At 47, Patricio has been engaged in the rice farming business for almost 20 years. He is married and has three school-aged children. Patricio's wife is his only partner in managing the business. They need to work harder to send their three children to school. 

Patricio is asking for a loan of P 20,000 to buy fertilizer, pesticides and seeds for rice production. He hopes that he will reap a large volume of rice to increase their income that will be used for food and their children's studies.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, pesticides and seeds for rice production.

location.town: Brgy. Bitnong, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Mahmud

texts.ru:
Махмуд женат и любящий отец. Махмуд более 15 лет занимается куплей-продажей обуви, и он имеет богатый опыт в данном бизнесе.  В этом бизнесе помогает ему его сын, дочь и супруга, потому что он имеет две торговые точки и день за днем его клиенты растут и ему необходимо надо помогать и поддерживать свой бизнес. Его старший сын усердно помогает своему отцу, и он ездит в Китай или в Бишкек за товарами. Махмуд хотел бы получит кредит в размере 1000$ США для покупки нового ассортимента обуви и расширение бизнеса. С прибылью, который он планирует получит он хочет устроит его сыновья в ВУЗ. Он надеется, что кредиторы будут поддерживать его, что позволит ему улучшить условие жизни семьи.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj
texts.en:
Mahmud is married and a loving father. For more than 15 years, Mahmud has been buying and selling shoes, and he has rich experience in this type of business. He is helped in this business by his son, daughter and wife, because he has two outlets and day by day his clients grow and he needs the help and support for his business. His eldest son especially helps his father, and he travels to China or to Bishkek for inventory. Mahmud would like to receive a loan for US $1000 in order to buy a new assortment of shoes to expand his business. With the profit that he plans to earn, he wants to send his sons to college. He hopes that a loan will support him allowing him to improve his family's quality of life.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase a new assortment of shoes

loans.name: Fakhriddin

texts.ru:
Фахриддин честный и ответственный муж. Он женат и любящий отец одного сына. Он преподает в школе и параллельно занимается выращиванием сельскохозяйственных культур.  Он выращивает картофель, морковь и пшеницу.  Раньше он получал кредит от Имон Интернэшнл и оно помогло ему в положительную сторону. Он увеличил оборотный капитал и улучшил условия его жизни. Теперь, он хотел бы получит еще кредит для покупки минеральное удобрение и мешки для его урожая. Фахриддин заранее хочет поблагодарит всех кредиторов за их поддержку и милосердие. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj
texts.en:
Fakhriddin is an honest and responsible man. He is married and a loving father of one son. He teaches in a school and at the same time is involved in growing crops. He grows potatoes, carrots and wheat. Previously, he received a loan from IMON International and it helped him in a positive way. He increased his working capital and improved his quality of life. Now, he would like to receive another loan to purchase mineral fertilizers and bags for his crops. Fakhriddin wishes in advance to thank his creditors for their support and kindness. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is 35 years old and a married woman with five children. They live in Padul, Solana, Cagayan. Padul is a rural place where you can find housewives getting busy with their household chores and involved in businesses to improve their living conditions. 

Rosemarie raise hogs for breeding for future sale. She had been in this business for almost four years. Currently, she earns about 2,500 PHP for each pig she was able to sell.

Rosemarie wants to strengthen her business and make frequent sales to earn additional profits for the sustenance of her family. She is now asking for a loan of 5,000 PHP to buy feed and vitamins for the sustainability of her hogs so that she could offer them at a higher cost upon distribution. 

In the future, Rosemarie would like to keep making better sales to generate more income and uplift her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for sustainability of hogs

loans.name: Johnson

texts.en:
Johnson is 54 years old, married to Ruth and they have three children.

He operates his retail shop in Naivasha town and has been doing the business for twenty-three years. He was introduced to KADET by one of our field officers and this will be his third loan. He plans to use the loan to buy flour, sugar and cooking fat in bulk, which he will then re-pack and sell in small quantities.

In future, Johnson hopes to grow his retail shop to wholesale.

loans.use: to buy flour, sugar and cooking fat in bulk

loans.name: Rufiji Group

texts.en:
Vissa, who is in her late 20s, is single. She has been running a business of selling fried chicken, fried bananas and fried chicken legs for four years now. She works from 2 p.m. to 11:30 p.m. daily (she works in the evenings only) and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be her 7th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to increase her business, paid room rent, bought house holdings like a bed, cupboard, cups, saucepans and has paid back all her loans successfully. She wants a loan to buy 10 pieces of chicken, 3 bundles of chicken legs, some Bananas and to save fifty thousand.

She will share this loan with her loan group "Rufiji", which has a total of 15 members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To  buy 10 pieces of chicken, 3 bundles of chicken legs, some Bananas and to save fifty thousand.
